ygData.subject: Re: Impressively Smart, Non-Evolved Neural Network

Subject: Re: Impressively Smart, Non-Evolved Neural Network
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=550414109; y=I0OOh7Yc-8MQnPLF0uizfCQ3mWs-ty8wxB2wzm5d1uZOWij8XuOYkKebafCLk3v0maHTe9Opx7mZntU

Short answer: I don't think either technique has been explored enough to de=
cisively show which technique is more promising. However, this paper highli=
ghts the kinds of cognitive tasks that researchers in evolved AI should be =
working on.


Longer answer:

Regarding their approach, it sounds similar-i=
sh to deep learning. They're training an ANN that compresses sensory inform=
ation into something that the ANN can handle, then training ANNs to perform=
 various tasks based on that compressed information. From what I can tell, =
they're training a different ANN for each task. However, each task isn't "p=
lay this video game" or "control this robot," but rather the tasks based on=
 areas of the brain: reward evaluation (orbitofrontal cortex), routing (tha=
lamus), motor processing (premotor cortex), etc.

Unfortunately the details=
 of the training algorithm seem to be locked up inside of a book that they =
conveniently just published. If someone has $100 to fork out to explore fur=
ther: http://www.amazon.com/How-Build-Brain-Architecture-Architectures/dp/0=
199794545


Will this technique be the path to AGI? It's possible, but I'm =
skeptical. (Rightfully so, the technique is still new.) Their brain archite=
cture is wisely designed since no area is dedicated to one specific task (e=
.g., there's no "play a video game" region). However, one thing they don't =
talk about here is how much retraining of all the brain regions is necessar=
y to add new functionality.

For example, what if we want Spaun to start re=
cognizing and working with images of animals and people as well? Will we on=
ly need to retrain the compression/decompression region, or will we have to=
 retrain everything to work with this new sensory input? Or what if we want=
 Spaun to start walking as well? Do we just need to retrain the motor proce=
ssing region to add functionality, or will we again need to retrain everyth=
ing? I think the answer to this question will be the deciding factor of how=
 effective this technique will be for building an AGI.


More importantly f=
or us, I was excited when I saw this paper because it highlighted the kinds=
 of cognitive tasks that AI researchers should be working on. We should aim=
 to evolve neural architectures that perform cognitive tasks much like Spau=
n. Receive visual input, process visual input, perform cognitive task based=
 on processed visual input, perform some physical action based off of resul=
t of cognitive task. AFAIK there hasn't been much neuroevolution work that =
does that, so it's hard to say whether neuroevolution will succeed or fail =
at it. Please link me to the literature if you know of any.

We've recently=
 published a paper on using neuroevolution for optical character recognitio=
n (http://adamilab.msu.edu/wp-content/uploads/Chapman-Evolution-of-an-artif=
icial-visual-cortex-for-image-recognition-2013.pdf), just as Spaun did. So =
that at least shows some promise of neuroevolution creating artificial brai=
n structures that can perform basic cognitive tasks.


--- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all,
> 
> At GECCO there =
were a few different conversations about whether neuroevolution remains a p=
romising path to AI given the progress being made in other AI/neural networ=
k areas relative to the progress in neuroevolution. One issue mentioned a f=
ew times was this recent paper that shows surprisingly impressive AI in a n=
on-evolved neural network. 	
> 
> http://clm.utexas.edu/compjclub/papers/El=
iasmith2012.pdf
> 
> Many people on this list expressed an interest in read=
ing this paper and discussing its techniques and implications on the NEAT l=
ist. 
> 
> I don't understand their learning mechanisms (because I have not=
 taken the time to read the papers they reference), but if someone does get=
 a good grasp on how the magic happens, please share your take. More genera=
lly, I'd be interested in any of your reactions regarding whether you agree=
 that this  is a very impressive level of intelligence (and well beyond wha=
t we can currently evolve) and whether that means we should question our de=
votion to neuroevolution as one of the quickest paths to AGI. I want to not=
e that I'm not (yet!) taking a position, but am just curious to hear what y=
ou think. 
> 
> Let the discussion begin!
> 
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clun=
e
>
